values.description:
sockets currently emit three events:

- `simulator_launch`

- `simulator_status`

- `simulator_terminate`

Callback has one parameter, a simulator object. It has the same format as the rest api simulator response object

`test/mocha/simulator/sockets.js` contains examples of how to authenticate with the socket server and listen to its events
values.title: Integrate sockets for aws instance status updates

summary.raw:
sockets currently emit three events:

- `simulator_launch`

- `simulator_status`

- `simulator_terminate`

Callback has one parameter, a simulator object. It has the same format as the rest api simulator response object

`test/mocha/simulator/sockets.js` contains examples of how to authenticate with the socket server and listen to its events
summary.html:
sockets currently emit three events:

  • simulator_launch

  • simulator_status

  • simulator_terminate

Callback has one parameter, a simulator object. It has the same format as the rest api simulator response object

test/mocha/simulator/sockets.js contains examples of how to authenticate with the socket server and listen to its events

values.description:
issue #2

new route: `/users/permissions`

pass in the simulator id, e.g. `{id:'some_id'}`, to check if user has read/write access to that simulator.  

If `id` is null then it checks to see if the user can launch a machine
values.title: Support checking if user can launch a machine

summary.raw:
issue #2

new route: `/users/permissions`

pass in the simulator id, e.g. `{id:'some_id'}`, to check if user has read/write access to that simulator.  

If `id` is null then it checks to see if the user can launch a machine
summary.html:
issue #2

new route: /users/permissions

pass in the simulator id, e.g. {id:'some_id'}, to check if user has read/write access to that simulator.

If id is null then it checks to see if the user can launch a machine

values.description:
Add `CLOUDSIM_PORTAL_DB` env variable. The variable specifies the URI of the database to connect to.

This is so that we can host the database on a different instance from the portal

values.description:
Similar to [this](#!/osrf/cloudsim-auth/pull-requests/6/https/diff) pull request for cloudsim-auth.

* Serve on `http` by default. Beanstalk's load balancer will be the one serving https.
* Add two ebextension files which together configure the beanstalk https.
* `.ebextensions/https-lbterminate.config` contains project-specific information, so it is generated prior to deployment with `bash ebextensions.bash <ARN> <VPC>`. The information is:
    * <ARN> of HTTPS certificate stored in ACM or IAM
    * <VPC> ID where elastic beanstalk was launched.
* As I mentioned in the other PR, `ebextensions.bash` looks ugly

Currently Codeship deployed the `http` branch and you can see that it is live in https://devportal.cloudsim.io/ . Before this PR is merged, I'll change the deployment pipeline to use the `default` branch instead.
values.title: HTTPS

summary.raw:
Similar to [this](#!/osrf/cloudsim-auth/pull-requests/6/https/diff) pull request for cloudsim-auth.

* Serve on `http` by default. Beanstalk's load balancer will be the one serving https.
* Add two ebextension files which together configure the beanstalk https.
* `.ebextensions/https-lbterminate.config` contains project-specific information, so it is generated prior to deployment with `bash ebextensions.bash <ARN> <VPC>`. The information is:
    * <ARN> of HTTPS certificate stored in ACM or IAM
    * <VPC> ID where elastic beanstalk was launched.
* As I mentioned in the other PR, `ebextensions.bash` looks ugly

Currently Codeship deployed the `http` branch and you can see that it is live in https://devportal.cloudsim.io/ . Before this PR is merged, I'll change the deployment pipeline to use the `default` branch instead.
summary.html:
Similar to this pull request for cloudsim-auth.

  • Serve on http by default. Beanstalk's load balancer will be the one serving https.
  • Add two ebextension files which together configure the beanstalk https.
  • .ebextensions/https-lbterminate.config contains project-specific information, so it is generated prior to deployment with bash ebextensions.bash <ARN> <VPC>. The information is:
    • <ARN> of HTTPS certificate stored in ACM or IAM
    • <VPC> ID where elastic beanstalk was launched.
  • As I mentioned in the other PR, ebextensions.bash looks ugly

Currently Codeship deployed the http branch and you can see that it is live in https://devportal.cloudsim.io/ . Before this PR is merged, I'll change the deployment pipeline to use the default branch instead.

values.description:
- add routes for creating / deleting groups, and updating group rules

- the `/simulators` POST API will now look for an optional `sgroup` argument in `body` to determine what security group to launch the simulator in. If not specified, no other instances will be able to connect to it (current default behavior). 

- there is some caching of rules but maybe I can look into removing that later

- for a group to give inbound access to another group, use the `/sgroups/:group` UPDATE API. See `Check Update Security Group with New Rule` test for an example
values.title: Support security groups

summary.raw:
- add routes for creating / deleting groups, and updating group rules

- the `/simulators` POST API will now look for an optional `sgroup` argument in `body` to determine what security group to launch the simulator in. If not specified, no other instances will be able to connect to it (current default behavior). 

- there is some caching of rules but maybe I can look into removing that later

- for a group to give inbound access to another group, use the `/sgroups/:group` UPDATE API. See `Check Update Security Group with New Rule` test for an example
summary.html:
• add routes for creating / deleting groups, and updating group rules

  • the /simulators POST API will now look for an optional sgroup argument in body to determine what security group to launch the simulator in. If not specified, no other instances will be able to connect to it (current default behavior).

  • there is some caching of rules but maybe I can look into removing that later

  • for a group to give inbound access to another group, use the /sgroups/:group UPDATE API. See Check Update Security Group with New Rule test for an example

values.description:
added parseResponse function to print debug info during tests.
Just pass true in a second argument.

This was created while looking for error running the portal tests on my computer.
The tests fail sometimes, but not always. So this PR adds tools, but doesn't fix any test.

values.description:
This PR replaces the socket implementation (server/socket.js) with the one in cloudsim-grant.
While the code is mostly the same (socket.js was "moved" to cloudsim-grant), the notifications are not the same. Thus, upstream projects (cloudsim-widgets) will have to upgrade.

* replace sockets with resource updates

* removed unused files

* comment edit

* added tests
values.title: Socket refactor

summary.raw:
This PR replaces the socket implementation (server/socket.js) with the one in cloudsim-grant.
While the code is mostly the same (socket.js was "moved" to cloudsim-grant), the notifications are not the same. Thus, upstream projects (cloudsim-widgets) will have to upgrade.

* replace sockets with resource updates

* removed unused files

* comment edit

* added tests
summary.html:
This PR replaces the socket implementation (server/socket.js) with the one in cloudsim-grant. While the code is mostly the same (socket.js was "moved" to cloudsim-grant), the notifications are not the same. Thus, upstream projects (cloudsim-widgets) will have to upgrade.

  • replace sockets with resource updates

  • removed unused files

  • comment edit

  • added tests

values.description:
To try it out:

`node launch_sim.js "test machine"`

You can then ssh in the machine and type: `sudo shutdown now`

Then, on the AWS console, verify that the machine is shutting down. This will be the default behavior on Cloudsim from now on, so that we can terminate the instance after running a simulation.
values.title: Changed shutdown behavior to 'Terminate' on AWS

summary.raw:
To try it out:

`node launch_sim.js "test machine"`

You can then ssh in the machine and type: `sudo shutdown now`

Then, on the AWS console, verify that the machine is shutting down. This will be the default behavior on Cloudsim from now on, so that we can terminate the instance after running a simulation.
summary.html:
To try it out:

node launch_sim.js "test machine"

You can then ssh in the machine and type: sudo shutdown now

Then, on the AWS console, verify that the machine is shutting down. This will be the default behavior on Cloudsim from now on, so that we can terminate the instance after running a simulation.

values.description:
Added a middleware for the instance limit check before launching a machine on AWS

Right now it checks the hardware string, i.e. g2.2xlarge. Later on we could limit instances by machine types and revert the changes in this PR.
values.title: Add workaround for limiting instance by hardware type

summary.raw:
Added a middleware for the instance limit check before launching a machine on AWS

Right now it checks the hardware string, i.e. g2.2xlarge. Later on we could limit instances by machine types and revert the changes in this PR.
summary.html:
Added a middleware for the instance limit check before launching a machine on AWS

Right now it checks the hardware string, i.e. g2.2xlarge. Later on we could limit instances by machine types and revert the changes in this PR.

values.description:
When we reset the database yesterday, all production servers stopped working. I'm redeploying them one by one, but portal production won't deploy because its scripts are outdated. 

‌

Porting default to production should allow the server to be deployed again.
values.title: Port default to production

summary.raw:
When we reset the database yesterday, all production servers stopped working. I'm redeploying them one by one, but portal production won't deploy because its scripts are outdated. 

‌

Porting default to production should allow the server to be deployed again.
summary.html:
When we reset the database yesterday, all production servers stopped working. I'm redeploying them one by one, but portal production won't deploy because its scripts are outdated.

‌

Porting default to production should allow the server to be deployed again.

values.description: on launch, the [generateScript](#!/osrf/cloudsim-portal/src/8d358936d83b94b175d663faa2eb10a0ccbf82a2/server/cloud_services.js?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#cloud_services.js-401) function in cloud_services.js creates a `/home/ubuntu/code/cloudsim-options.json` file on the instance machine and populates it with the `options` data. The instance machine can now post back to the portal to terminate itself if needed
values.title: Pass sim id to simulation instance via options

summary.raw: on launch, the [generateScript](#!/osrf/cloudsim-portal/src/8d358936d83b94b175d663faa2eb10a0ccbf82a2/server/cloud_services.js?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#cloud_services.js-401) function in cloud_services.js creates a `/home/ubuntu/code/cloudsim-options.json` file on the instance machine and populates it with the `options` data. The instance machine can now post back to the portal to terminate itself if needed
summary.html: on launch, the generateScript function in cloud_services.js creates a /home/ubuntu/code/cloudsim-options.json file on the instance machine and populates it with the options data. The instance machine can now post back to the portal to terminate itself if needed

values.description:
This PR adds a new simulator metrics endpoint, which initially just keeps track of instance-hours used by each user/team.

As a separate pull request there will be a new middleware to reject requests if the max number of hours for the user/team was reached.
values.title: Initial simulator metrics

summary.raw:
This PR adds a new simulator metrics endpoint, which initially just keeps track of instance-hours used by each user/team.

As a separate pull request there will be a new middleware to reject requests if the max number of hours for the user/team was reached.
summary.html:
This PR adds a new simulator metrics endpoint, which initially just keeps track of instance-hours used by each user/team.

As a separate pull request there will be a new middleware to reject requests if the max number of hours for the user/team was reached.
